J.B.,

Thanks for the reply. I'm not exactly sure what you mean by
"Monostate," but I understand your concern on the static methods. My
developers' group is meeting on Wednesday and one of the topics is
going to be allowing my project to use Spring. If that happens, I will
eliminate the AppProperties and have each component that needs
properties have a setter for the specific property.

Also, I ordered your book from Amazon about three weeks ago and I am
anxiously awaiting its arrival (it is supposed to be delivered
7/12-7/28). I have heard nothing but rave reviews.

Michael.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> Michael wrote:
> > Hi, all. I have a testing scenario I need help with. The application I
> > am working on has a class called AppProperties. This class has a lot
> > of static methods on it for loading properties files and getting
> > properties back out:
> > 
> > public void loadProperties() {
> >    //reads properties from classpath
> >    AppProperties.addResource("app.properties");
> >    AppProperties.addResource("MessageResources.properties");
> > }
> > 
> > public void performTest() {
> >    boolean test = AppProperties.getBoolean("app.perform.test");
> >    if (test) {
> >       ...
> >    }
> > }
> > 
> > This scenario is not very testable. I like the idea of a static class
> > to pull application properties from, but it makes testing more
> > difficult. I could load the AppProperties object in the setUp (that is
> > my solution to get it working until I get better suggestions), but it
> > seems like the app should be designed a little differently. How would
> > something like this be handled in IoC (DI) projects?
> 
> I don't much like the Monostate you have there. Even a true Singleton 
> would be a little better than all those class-level method invocations.
> 
> Injecting the dependency is simple: classes than need application 
> properties add a constructor parameter or set() method that takes an 
> AppProperties implementation. Now in tests, I can set up the data in 
> AppProperties any way I want for the test. (In fact, I wouldn't do it 
> that way, but that's another article.) In production code, I might have 
> AppProperties be a Singleton and, in one place, invoke 
> AppProperties.getInstance(), then inject that instance into all the 
> objects that need it, either in code or through a DI container like
Spring.
> 
> For the "advanced" answer, I'll just have to write the article, but 
> here's the summary: don't have classes depend on AppProperties, but 
> rather on the data you want from it. Centralize getting the 
> AppProperties data in one place.
> --
